headline.main: A Town of Guinea Pigs Celebrates Its Contribution to Longer Life

docs.abstract: Framingham Heart Study marks 50th anniversary, and gala party in Framingham, Mass, will honor the people whose faithful submission to all kinds of tests and questionnaires over the years has enabled scientists to greatly increase their understanding of heart disease and to help countless Americans lead longer, healthier lives; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: If all the Americans who owe some of the length or quality of their lives to the Framingham Heart Study were to express their gratitude by attending its 50th anniversary gala on Sunday afternoon, the auditorium would need millions upon millions of folding chairs. ''It would be fair to say that Framingham has arguably contributed more than any other town in the United States to advance the health of our nation,'' said Dr. Daniel Levy, the study's director, who will be at the gala.
docs.snippet: If all the Americans who owe some of the length or quality of their lives to the Framingham Heart Study were to express their gratitude by attending its 50th anniversary gala on Sunday  afternoon, the auditorium would need millions upon millions of...

headline.main: Dietary Supplements May Test Consumers' Health

docs.abstract: Personal Health column on potential danger of substances loosely referred to as dietary supplements; The New England Journal of Medicine cites reports from six physicians of such reactions as lead poisoning, impotence, blood clots, abnormal heart rhythms, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and disorientation from exposure to powerful drugs or toxic contaminants in products deemed to be 'all natural' alternatives to established therapies; editorial in journal calls for rigorous testing of all products, saying scientific community must stop giving alternative medicine a free ride; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: GROWING numbers of Americans are stepping daily into a potential minefield of substances loosely referred to as dietary supplements, many of which have little or nothing to do with the components of foods people normally consume. And increasingly these pill poppers are getting into trouble, suffering toxic reactions to deliberate or accidental components of these products or sacrificing the chance to be helped by conventional medicine. Last week in six reports published in The New England Journal of Medicine, physicians described such reactions as lead poisoning, impotence, blood clots, abnormal heart rhythms, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and disorientation from exposure to powerful drugs or toxic contaminants in products deemed to be ''all natural'' alternatives to established therapies. The reports are a reminder that consumers who wander recklessly into the world of herbs and other dietary supplements must proceed at their own risk because no regulatory agency has the authority to assess the safety, purity or effectiveness of these products before they can be sold to the public.
